title: Q680 V3 Landing Gear/ Battery Holder/ Gimbal

description.text:
Bought a Q680 from Hobbyking? Daunted at the task of mounting stuff to it? Never fear, i've gone through the hassle so you don't have to. Included in this kit is:  
-Landing gear kit designed for 5.4mm (marked .210") Carbon fiber  (Previous 8mm version tested, 5.4mm version untested)  
-Battery retainer kit for select batteries  (Tested, functional)  
-Modified TBS Discovery brushless gopro Gimbal parts (STOCK parts are directly taken from NATHAN_'s design, some parts are modified to work with a 16mm motor)  (UNTESTED)  
Check the instructions for specifics on the electronics setup I used and required parts.

Required parts: Landing Gear:
5.4mm (marked .210") Carbon fiber or similar durable rod
4x leg joint, 2 normal, 2 mirrored
2x landing gear mount, 1x if using gimbal
1x landing gear gimbal mount if using gimbal. !Instructions coming soon! Battery holder:
1" or smaller velcro, cut to size
4 4-40 bolts and matching nuts
1x Battery base
2x battery holder !This battery holder works with 142x49x43 or smaller batteries only. ANY LARGER BATTERIES WILL NOT FIT! If you truly have a need for a quadcopter that has a longer endurance than many feature-length movies, or want to put on a smaller battery let me know, and i can alter parts!
!Instructions coming soon! Gimbal:
2x Brushless motor
1x Gimbal Controller
1x Gopro Hero 3/4
4x shock dampener thingies http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00FJSA2Y2/ref=wms_ohs_product?ie=UTF8&psc=1
(I'm assuming if you planned to put the gimbal on, you will have already added the "landing gear gimbal mount" part to your build plate. If not, please do so)
1x motor plate (STOCK)
1x camera holder (12 or 16mm, take your pick)
1x gimbal arm (12 or 16mm, take your pick) !Instructions coming soon-ish! Don't have a Q680 yet? Here's what i got for mine. (mileage may vary) Controller: HKPIlot (Chinese for APM) Master set http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__58283__HKPilot_Mega_2_7_Master_Set_With_OSD_LEA_6H_GPS_Power_module_Telemetry_Radio_915Mhz_XT_60_.html 10s capable voltage meter: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__56855__HKPilot_Mega_10s_Power_Module_With_XT60_Connectors.html ESC: AFRO 20a HV http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__42549__Afro_HV_20A_MultiRotor_ESC_High_Voltage_3_8s.html Motor: Multistar Elite 268kv http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__63642__Multistar_Elite_3508_268KV_High_Voltage_Endurance_Motor.html?strSearch=268kv Prop: 15x 5.5 CF
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__34403__Multirotor_CF_Propeller_Pair_15_x_5_5_Left_and_Right_Rotation_To_Suit_Pancake_Motors.html Performance:
AUW (no camera) 2KG, just a hair over
Endurance: 45 Minutes, no wind hover
Max pitch speed at full throttle: 31mph
Acrobatics: NO
Flies well on the stock Mission Planner PIDs, but some tuning may make it peform better yet. Mileage may vary, I am not responsible for lost fingers/injuries (CF PROPS ARE SHARP!)

There are many syringe pump designs available - just search Thingiverse! While most of these designs are very capable and can be built for various syringe sizes, they often require many vitamins (non-plastic parts), like guide rods and bearings. My goal was to create a syringe pump for a 10ml syringe that needs a minimum of vitamins. Here is the result. The Instructions explain how to assemble the pump and other important details. The FreeCAD design files will be available  on GitHub.  
Use this with my Simple Servo Valve (coming soon) to build a pump that can continuously deliver a fluid from a source to a destination.

Print one of each part except for the rails: print two of these.
I print the carriage with support. The nut hole is hard to clean out, but leaves a nearly perfect opening to shove the M8 nut into.
In addition to the printed parts, you'll need:
1 M8 nut (for the carriage)
120mm of M8 threaded rod
4 10mm x M3 screws (for the motor)
8 20mm x M3 screws (for the frame)
4 12mm x M3 screws (for the clamps)
1 10ml syringe
1 NEMA 17 stepper motor
Shaft coupling of some sort. The coupling design I use is discussed here: https://hackaday.io/project/3794/logs. If you use it, you'll need some brass tubing, 3 10mm x M3 screws, 3 M3 nuts, and 1 6mm x M3 set screw. I use an M3 tap to thread the holes in the rails, the carriage, and the clamp holes in the syringe holder. The pictures show how to assemble the unit. I use Teensy 2 (Arduino clone), a 5V source (for the servo), and a stepper driver to run the pump.

comments.text:
Have noticed its really tough to get the support material out for the moving part - I tried pausing the build when the lower section was completed just before the top layer was started - then placing the M8 nut in situ. This meant the top layer wasn't being built with lots of bridging and came out very well.
My main problem with the design is its not very rigid - maybe a baseplate or such would be useful ?

This is a surfboard fin, modeled in sketchup using measurements and scans, calipers so on for guidance. Thickness is not different leading/trailing edge, but is somewhat accurate to the basic slope of the real fin.

• Print using the split STL files if your printer can't fit the larger one.
  • Use support material, and print slower than normal to aid the overhangs.

This is a gear that can be driven using the 4.5mm beaded belt, or ball chain obtainable from many hardware stores. This is useful for general drive applications, but was originally designed for the Z axis on RepRap Darwins.

Peel off bits of raft and lightly ream the centre hole to remove any trailing filament. Push an M8 hex nut into the hexagonal cavity - it should be a snug fit. If it is too snug warm the plastic with a hairdryer to reduce the chance of splitting the gear.
Fix on M8 studding by applying a washer and another nut to the flat side of the gear and tightening against the gear. The trapped nut provides a good key onto the drive shaft and reduces the need for washers.
The "95" refers to the scaling factor applied over my calculated dimensions. Scaling up and down by a few % may be needed if your chain is slightly out or your printer extrusion isn't quite perfect.

description.text: A countertop rack for hanging plastic bags or bottles to dry. OpenSCAD files are also included. An .stl file for printing only one bar top is included, since I needed to print one offs a number of times. Note: For printing you only need the .stl files!

    • Because the posts stand so high, they can get wobbly, that's why the large raft is important. To attach the extension posts to the base, I sanded the pins on the top of the base a bit, and then used Superglue.

On my first one, the extension posts didn't end up being as straight as I wanted them to be when I glued them to the base. To fix this, I've made a gluing jig to use to hold the post straight while the glue dries. You can find it here.
Shared constants are stored in the common.scad file that is included in the others.

A parametric Unicorn Horn, for attaching to the foreheads of things that need their awesomeness enhanced.
This is my first experiment with using OpenSCAD.  A friend of mine is making an NES case mod and he needed a unicorn horn (don't ask).  I searched through Thingiverse, but all I could find were prints for the pen plotter.  Clearly, this needed to be fixed.
The design is just a parametric spiral with a bit of an offset to make it seem twisty and more natural. It's made entirely with blobs, which gives it a really cool texture when it prints.
I tried to put in pins for alignment, but I could never get them to print cleanly enough.  The spiral was a good enough guide for me, but someone who's better at OpenSCAD might be able to get it to work.

I wanted a horn about 8 inches high, so I printed it in four pieces. I managed a 1/8th scale print as a single part, but it's basically too tall to print as one piece. Here's what I did to print the horn.
  • Print the unicorn_horn_print.stl file. If you're really brave and your table doesn't shake like mine does, you might be able to get away with printing unicorn_horn.stl
  • Break off the bridges between the parts. A hobby knife helps to remove the ridges.
  • Sand the top and bottom of each piece flat. My printer curls the edges on the base pretty obviously, so it helps to sand the middle down a bit. Try to get the pieces flat and parallel or the horn will come out crooked.
  • Align the parts. The horn has a counter-clockwise spiral and the ridges from the print supports can help align the horn parts.
  • Superglue everything together. I pressed each section together, then let it set for ten minutes. Any gaps can be filled with superglue, which melts the ABS together and produces a nice finish.
    • After a little sanding, the horn looks pretty good.

See http://github.com/uplake/BezierScad Updated 5/10/13--fixed triangle winding in centered BezWall; use polyhedron for variable-height BezArc. I wanted a bezier library that could handle an arbitrary number of control points. When working on thingiverse.com/thing:77586, I also wanted to rotate extrude a "wall" defined by a bezier path and a width. BezWall is the workhorse function. The "ctlPts" parameter accepts between 1-8 bezier control points. The parameters "width" and "height" accept static values (e.g., 5) specifying the width and height of the wall. If height is 0, it will generate a 2d object you can extrude yourself. The alternate parameters "widthCtls" and "heightCtls" accept an array of values that will be bezier-interpolated along the length of the wall. If the "centered" parameter is "true", the wall is centered on the path defined by "ctlPts". Otherwise, one edge of the wall is defined by "ctlPts". At the moment, there is no documentation! But there is a test file that runs through most of the available features.

I'd previously done some work writing coffeescript code to generate bezier interpolation functions that accept an arbitrary number of control points, and I'd written some coffeescript to generate openscad code. It occurred to me that I could use coffeescript to automate a lot of the tedium in writing openscad functions. So, the coffeescript file in this thing will generate openscad functions to handle bezier interpolation with a varying number of control points. The attached BezierScad.scad file can deal with up to 8 control points, but you can easily modify orderMax in the coffeescript file to have it generate functions that can deal with higher or lower orders.  
The BezLine function is simpler than BezWall and offers a subset of the BezWall functionality.   
BezLine takes an array of 1-8 control points and an array of 1-8 width values, which will be bezier interpolated as widths for the resulting line.   
BezLine doesn't accept a "steps" parameter. Rather, it takes a "resolution" parameter of between 2-6. The resulting line will have (2**resolution) segments.  
BezArc returns a shape similar to that generated by WilliamAAdams' BezQuadCurve function.

description.text: I didn't like the idea of using continuous-rotation servos in my InMoov project, but was unhappy with the ratio in the standard InMoov rotGear/rotWorm, so I created my own. This is very experimental (call it alpha)- so I'm looking for feedback! More info here: http://mhespenh.ninja/replacement-worm-gearset/

This is a 2.5:1 drop-in replacement for the stock InMoov rotGear and rotWorm (and a spacer). This will rotate the big gear once every 2.5 rotations of the servo, so a normal 180° servo going end-to-end will rotate the big gear ~72°. I don't know exactly what the ratio on the stock gears are, but it appears to be around 15:1. gearSpacer goes between rotGear and rotTit, tabs face towards the rotGear (flat side towards rotTit)- you can glue the spacer to rotGear if you want. [See second photo] This will only fit in the bicep- I'll upload a version for the shoulder soon.

• I have done very little testing of these gears, so use at your own risk! Please provide feedback if you use them!
  • You will lose a LOT of stall torque with this setup by virtue of the gear ratios, so this is a conscious trade-off: Speed for power. (IE: you can easily rotate the servo-end by turning the big-gear, which you can't (easily) with the stock setup).
  • This gear train is way more sensitive to friction/sloppy printing than the stock setup, so you need to have your printer working well to get this to run smoothly.

• 06 June 2015: Initial commit
  • 07 June 2015: Uploaded corrected STLs (previously were oriented incorrectly, otherwise unchanged)
  • 07 June 2015: Added gearSpacer as a shim to force gear and worm into alignment when under pressure of arm hanging off it.

• 0.3mm layer height
  • 3 shells
  • 20% infill
  • no support, no brim/raft.
    • gearSpacer needs to be printed at 0.3mm layer height so it is exactly 0.9mm high (minus the alignment tabs) I have done limited testing so you may need to increase infill and shells for strength. Set layer height to whatever you can print best at. Some fine-sanding will be required.

comments.text: I got it working thank you. Sanding a bit yea thanks again. :)
comments.author: Adolph

comments.text:
Hi,
This modification should work for the "rotate" section, but won't work for the "shoulder" section. The torque needed for this worm gear will be huge to lift the arm, not mentionning adding weight in the hand (currently InMoov can lift 1.5kg at end of the arm). Using this modification in the "shoulder" without extracting the potentiometer might still not rotate enough to get the full motion of the arm.
Please post a video on the InMoov site when you have done some tests!
We always like to see new things coming up.

title: E3D bowden setup for ORD-Bot Hadron (Ordbot)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my personal best fit (well currently at least) for mounting an E3D on an Ordbot Hadron. I couldn't find something that i found to be good for me so i just built one myself. A video from the first print is available on Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O2TRUi11mMo Some facts that you might want to know:
  • it was built vor E3D V6 but should most probably also fit other version (not yet tested, feedback welcome)
  • it was built using Autodesks Fusion360. F360 file as well es step and iges files are available in the downloads - feel free to modify but please respect the license. Fusion360 is free for startups and enthusiasts - you should give it a try.
  • I am loving heat inserts instead of nut traps, therefore i used them in this setup. The bottom ones are for M4 (4mm) screws, the upper one for M3 (3mm) that's why the whole fit for these heat inserts (got mine from Inserts direct in the UK).
  • The feeder is an MK7 feeder from Robotdigg - i may change this setup soon as i had problems printing Filaflex (flexible Filament) - guess this could be optimized even though it's a bowden setup).
    • The STLs are design with a bit of a gap between parts that stick together. This is true for the clamping part and the stuff that slips into the makerslide. I'd love to hear your feedback and will try to answer questions.

title: FPV Goggle magnifying glasses holder (Cyclop Eye 5)

description.text:
This is a holder specifically for these lenses: http://www.banggood.com/4-Lens-Headband-LED-Head-Light-Magnifier-Magnifying-Glass-Loupe-p-950353.html They will clip on. If it's too tight, you may have to file the opening a little wider. Use either a M3 or M4 screw and a nut/lock nut.
For me, the 2.5x ones work best with a 5" monitor at about half way down the slot.
It should be easy to use this lens holder with any DIY facebox by simply providing a 4-5mm wide slot at the top. The biggest advantage is the highly clear image, without the loss of quality from a fresnel type lens. There's still some pillow effect distortion at the the edges, though, depending on which lens is used.

Printed in PETG at 15% infill. Hardware needed: M3 or M4 bolt (10mm for normal nut, 14mm for lock nut)
M4 washer (works for either, larger surface area than m3 washer)
M3 or M4 nut or lock nut.
Magnifying lenses from this kit: http://www.banggood.com/4-Lens-Headband-LED-Head-Light-Magnifier-Magnifying-Glass-Loupe-p-950353.html

title: rp3d Pangu i3 Extruder Mount for Chinese All Metal J-Head (e3d clone)

description.text: This is a modification of the standard direct drive J-Head extruder mount that comes with the uber cheap rp3d Pangu i3 from Aliexpress. The J-Head that the original was designed for is considerably more expensive and not as common on Aliexpress than the cheap all-metal hot ends (e3d v5 clones I think?) also sold as J-Heads. While the mounting collar is similar, it's a difference size and so the all metal extruder doesn't fit in the original mount, also I wasn't that enamoured with the two-loose-screws which secure the original J-Head into the mount. This modification provides for a solid clip-in mount and has a secondary part to retain the extruder if necessary, on my print it's pretty tight press-fit, I suspect that the retention clip can be omitted entirely. The retention holes are 3mm diameter, probably some M3 screws will self tap in there with the usual shrinkage if you do need to put it on. Note that you will need to change your z stop, as the extruder is a bit longer. Have tested it, works well, as suspected the retaining piece does not appear to be necessary for me, but your milage may vary (if your print isn't such a tight fit). Recommend fan on at 100% all the time if you don't have a fan on the extruder heatsink itself (recommended). This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3QmSzXafVSq

Box for RLC meter designed by Nikita Afanasyev. It is made to fit the PCB designed by Aleksandar Krstic (pcb rev1.0) The link for the RLC meter (description of use, schematic, firmware, discussion): http://radiokot.ru/circuit/digital/measure/108/ The link for the PCB's: http://dirtypcbs.com/view.php?share=6586&accesskey=cad38a0e9484b06ec39b33055847b133 This is the best DIY RLC meter available today so I strongly suggest you make yourself one if you don't already have a proper RLC meter :) SolidWorks source files available with STL files

RLC.stl is the main body of the box. I print it as it is (top of the box up) with support inside the box, depending on the type of your machine you might want to remove the embossed letters on the top face and print face down, it will save you some plastic, no support mess to clean etc.. poklopac.stl is the bottom cover of the box. Print it on the side to have max strength of the hinge. print with 100% infill (or less if your machine is not calibrated properly) jezik.stl is the lip, the leg that allows you to hold the case at some degree up, it latches to the hinge on the bottom cover, also print on the side for max strength, if you print flat it will break when you try to latch. print with 100% infill (or less if your machine is not calibrated properly) Video showing lip function (note this is before the final print so here the bottom cover is manually cut to find the proper dimensions and the lip is 5mm shorter then in final version)
https://youtu.be/GEYoMIFXufg

author: tmash

description.text: Human head of a bald male without any expression (looking at infinite), to be printed in halves and glued together. Made to be put horizontally, with chin up (tilted back, not so stable position, but can be fixed up by enlarging neck base size or rafting some large base). The parts (left and right) of the face are simmetrical producing an well looking piece. There are some fine details (ears, eyes, nose and lips) that demand a very precise profile for printing (see attached files, for an example).

Since the print produces two parts, you will need to work on them to get the piece together. I recommend some sandpaper preparation to flaten the straight surface before using the glue to put it together (do not flat too much, because you may lose the nose and lips details). Some XYZ even scaling could be used to distort (or correct) the model. Preferably printed on MakerBot ThingOMatic with stepstruder MK6 (or you will need some very tricky adjustments, mainly to oozebane the profile).

author: sterndesignworks

description.text:
This is a recreation of my old
"Progressing Cavity Pump (cycloidical)" model
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28237
with slight modifications keeping physical backward compatibility.
plus methods to calculate the exact throughput based on pump geometry and drive frequency.
https://github.com/lsuess/scad-lib-cyclogearprofiles

1) It's a good usage example for the new library
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:777936
2) compatibility - for the people who already have printed an instance from the old code
3) reverse engineering of the old code was needed to calculate the pumps throughput.
some math with these pumps:
https://cloud.sagemath.com/projects/673e5d6c-1ece-46f0-818d-dc7e2e0e6358/files/Moineau%20Pump%20Math.sagews
If you spot some errors in there (very probable)
I'd hghly appreciate it if you'd notify me about them.

If you stack a left and a right version together and put an inlet part inbetween you can perfectly balance out the axial forces- on the rotor.
In that case the bearings for the drive do not need to take high loads of axial thrust. in effect this adds a second pump in parallel and doubles throughput
Assuming a water pumping application a double-sided symmetric underwater drive may be necessary. Put several of these in parallel to increase flow further.
putting them in series has little benefit (except slightly better sealing maybe for pumps that are printed with high clearance and that pump low viscosity fluids)

comments.text:
It is the basic design , the way a progressive cavity pump works.
The core of the stator needs to be a heavy elastomer , such as (Alumilite High Strength 3 RTV silicone).
With out a flexible inner core the rotor will not seal. If you would like , I can take a pic of a core ant the building mold used to make it.
comments.author: JML31347

title: Sony A6000 hot shoe cover & bounce flash

description.text:
Very simple device that combines both functions:
  • sony alpha 6000 hot shoe cover
  • an always ready flash bounce system
    • Install it on the camera and leave it forever, il will always be there when you'll need it and the hotshoe contacts are protected ;-)
    http://youtu.be/nDffY_Z3mf4 Being able to angle the flash to bounce light off the ceiling will create a better looking image many times. Most digital cameras have a flash that only faces forward. This will burn your subject with hard light many times. The Alpha 6000 will do the job using this simple device:
  • pop the flash unit out of its box,
  • push the head of the flash toward the screen
  • push the carbon rod to the right
    • Isn't this a KISS concept ? (Keep It Smart and Simple) EDIT: I moved the pin 2 mm forwards which allows to trim the angle of the flash just sliding backwards the hotshoe cover...

just print it in PLA
drill the hole at 2mm
insert a piece of 2mm carbon rod (or any other material) The hole diameter shall adjusted so that the carbon rod moves with some friction.

author: aeropic

description.text: Here's a flat cap for a 5" pvc post.

This cap has an inner and outer wall on it to make a good seal when gluing this on the end of a post. If glueing, use lots of PVC glue in the channel and on the post if you are looking for a water tight fit.  Print with 100% fill for a sturdy cap.

This is a carrying tote I put together. It is 7" x 7" and each compartment (eight in total) is 2" x 2" x 1.5"  
(Update: the original model had a bottom thickness of 0.5". It has been reduced to 0.25").

A parametric photographic filter case - just edit the file for the filter and screw size you require and use openscad to generate a DXF ready for laser cutting. As laid out it will house a single thin filter. If you're wanting to store thicker filters like variable ND or circular polarisers then you can just cut extra layers.  
To create a box for multiple filters of different sizes just set the case size to a fixed value large enough for the biggest filter and generate a file for each of the filter sizes you want to store. The screw holes will all line up and you can bolt together a filter box as wide as you require using threaded bar rather than bolts.  
This is my first attempt at a design in OpenSCAD - please be kind!  
Updates are most welcome!

author: darrenanton

title: Letus MCS style ShoulderPad Plate for Manfrotto 501 plate system

description.text:
Similar to the Letus MCS ShoulderPad/Plate design, but for the Manfrotto 501 plate system. Rather than attaching up the center, the attachment will be on either end of the plate, via countersunk screws coming up from the bottom into a railblock a la 'tripod mounting plates'. In place of the center column of screw holes will be a countersunk area for velcro attachment. The guide screw channels for the tripod attachment will still be in place. For those unfamiliar with the Master Cinema Series setup, the mounting plate serves as a hub for a shoulder pad which is secured via velcro. When the rig is not being used as a shoulder setup, one can remove the shoulder pad, and place the rig right onto the tripod. This sort of setup solves a few issues: 1) Simplifies and shortens the length of the rig
2) Removes the necessity for a separate mounting plate
3) Places the camera on top of the shoulder for smoother stability One could also use the basis of the design for a long plate that might better serve the stability of a shoulder setup.

author: kingstar

remixed_from.author: GregFrost
remixed_from.title: 3 Jaw Z Coupling for Prusa Mendel

title: 3 Jaw Z Coupling for Prusa Mendel

description.text: This is a new 3-jaw coupling that allows z alignment adjustment but doesn't require you to drill dimples in a nut and hang the x axis from the dimples.

The coupling is printed in 2 parts referred to below as the coupling and the cup.
I suggest you don't use a heated bed because you want to be able to remove the print from the bed easily to avoid snapping off one of the flanges.
Once you have printed both parts and safely removed them from the bed, insert 3 M3 nuts in the captive holes. The flanges on the inside should hold them in place once you get them in there.
Now lock two nuts on the top of your z rod. If the bridge over the top of the coupling has sagged a bit, you may not have room for two full nuts and may want to use a locknut (half nut) on the top. If this is the case, screw them on far enough so that the rod sits with the bottom of the bottom nut in line with the bottom of the coupling.
Put a washer on the rod smooth side down. Now slide the cup up the rod onto the bottom of the coupling so the holes are aligned. You may need some force to get the coupling to sit down in the cup. Once it is all the way on, the holes should be aligned and you should be able to see the captive nuts.
Screw 3 M3x10 or M3x12 screws into the nuts. These screws both hold the z rod up and allow you to adjust Z rod alignment.
Install the Z rod on your bot and attach to the stepper like you do with the standard coupling. I like to pre-drill the stepper hole using a 4.8mm drill bit and then put it on as a press fit before installing the screw and tightening tight.
Turn the z rod by hand and adjust the 3 jaw screws to precisely control the alignment of your z rod.
Print without any Z wobble.

description.text:
Xiaomi Yi Cam doesnt fit out of box. And it was impossible to get Video Out for FPV or quick SD Card access. So I created this one.  
Printed on ABS with 50% infill its 16gr for me. Same weight as the original holder.  
EDIT: As I still have no feedback from my testers I uploaded v4 to test, since v1 have some problems. Its pretty similar to the nice remix. Any feedback would be cool. I dont have spare time to test

I suggest printing in ABS/PETG or similar material (PLA is not so good) because you need to drill a M3 thread. The other screws are for drilling a M2.5 Thread. You will need some longer M2.5 screws than the original ones. And you will need a 1/4" screw to fixate the camera. I bought some 1$ cheap camera screws on banggood: http://www.banggood.com/14-Inch-Camera-Screws-For-Camera-Tripod-Monopod-Quick-Release-p-926699.html

author: Barracdil

description.text: The proteasome is the cell's recycler. Within this barrel-shaped complex, proteins are literally torn apart and chewed to shreds. How is such a brutal destruction machine controlled? Well, through the use of various caps and adaptor complexes of course! This set of models includes the regulatory complex from trypanosomes (1FNT) "proteasomecap.stl"; the activator complex from yeast (1VSY) "proteasomeactivator.stl"; and finally the ubiquitin identifying complex also from yeast (4B4T) "ubidentifier.stl" Each regulatory complex has also been modified to contain pegs that fit into holes in the flat sides of the proteasome barrel. Thus, each complex cam be attached reversibly to either side of the proteasome, assuming your printer is properly calibrated. Go here to learn more http://tinyurl.com/dyrf9hd

I printed this at 0.15mm layer height, 0.45mm extrusion width with natural ABS; I used KISSlicer's "dense" support setting and scaled the support flow rate to 70%.  
Removing support from inside the proteasome barrel is very difficult; I used a piece of armature wire stuck in the holes in the walls between the subunits. That said I did print a lot of these things before I got tired of them so I think it's totally worth it.

comments.text: At first glance I thought that was just a printer FUBAR.  Ah Nature's genuis huh?

Case for Qi DIY Wireless Charger:
http://goo.gl/DaxKui Made in great http://moi3d.com. Sources (3dm files) included. Closed using four 5x5mm pieces of double sided tape.

I have designed a dodecahedron lamp combining laser cut methacrylate and 3D printing for the joining parts.   
Would need to print 20 joint parts, preferably on transparent PLA, and use 60 countersunk M3 /10mm length bolts, and another 60 M3 nuts 2mm height.   
For the acrylic I have uploaded nesting files for two A3 sheets (297X420mm). Thickness of the methacrylate shall be 3mm, if thicker the join parts wont fit. Laser engraved on one panel is the url to this website to create a physical link to the 3d models, somehow.   
For the lamp I have used a Compact Fluorescent GX53 but there are many LED bulbs compatible to this lamp holder.  It serves as a container if turned upside down.   
Manufactured at/with the FabLab Barcelona

author: rinku

description.text: Folding_handle
Acrylic Filament holder with 3D printed gimbal.

Glue together laser cut parts using your preferred glue.  3D printed parts snap together, parts are held in place with M3 screws.  I tapped the top holes that hold the gimbal, you may choose to drill them out and use a screw with nut.  The Hub is suited to UP!+ 700g spool so you may want to make your own hub if using different spools.  
The holder can accommodate spools up to 100mm across or 2 standard spools at 58mm wide and 220mm in diameter.  The gimbal allows for placement anywhere near your printer.  
The door can be optional, bending can be done by placing the part in an oven at 120 degrees Celsius until the acrylic becomes soft and plyable, using gloves, place the headed acrylic over something with radius of around 127mm to form the curve, hold until cool. A large cooking pot may do the job.   
You will also need a rod around 8mm diameter for the spool and hub to rest on.  I used 12mm diameter stainless steel with 4mm wide grooves machined to 8.5mm diameter, 124mm apart.

52mm Fan blade with extended drive shaft
Hole Dia: 2mm
45 Degree Blades
Total Length = 26mm Blade Pictured is a bit rough, it was built at .25 layer height, accelerated speed, I was in a hurry.

author: crawdadfjb

description.text: As understood from its title it is a holder for the RVOSD pitot

My Overlord Pro printer has a problem; the cable bundle and filament tube gets caught in the belt in one of the columns when it parks the head after a print job. So, this is a sphere you clamp onto the cable bundle to stop that from happening.

You need to print 2 of both parts, the sphere and the clamps. If you feel artistic, they can be printed in different colours, even. I printed all parts in one go which took just under 2 hours.
The clamps can be a bit fiddly to fit onto the ends of the tube, but perseverance pays off. If the sphere doesn't stay in position, but slowly slides down, open it and add a piece of a rubber band in it together with the cable bundle.
Remember to rotate the sphere in your favorite slicer, so that the flat is facing down.

description.text:
This is a protection case for your Hubsan X4 with a magnetic cover to keep the drone safe while stored or transported.  
There is the place to add up to 6 LiPo batteries and spare parts like propellers, USB card or propeller tool.  
Originally designed for the H107C model, the H107D and H107L models should fit too  
UPDATE : The cover now includes a slot for the U wrench to remove the props, a slot for a USB charger for 2 or 4 LiPo and a groove to wrap the USB cable.
To keep the box closed, you just have to put a 4mm diameter neodym magnet in each holes (2 in the case and 2 in the cover)

description.text:
Just I start to create something by 3D printing. I already design to make some models which nobody make this before. And I want the topic is more related to our life. "The slave of house" is the first making. And now the second is come. It is about a student girl selfie. In recent years, we can found so much people selfie and selfie. He or she will have a strange face look while taking photo. It become a trend and most girl got special skill of selfie and makeup. I draw it by Meshmixer for one and a half day. This is my first time to draw a girl in 3D and using Meshmixer for it . Before it I think is it good to use Zbrush for working. But I found Zbrush is not free and most user of 3D printer already got the Meshmixer. It good to use this program for this work to show all the user that "I can do it ,you also can do it ". The height overall is 7.5cm. I print it small to test all the detail can be keep or not. It seems cannot to be smaller than it while some details are being disappeared. I print it on 0.1mm and by PLA. And I separate into 5 part with support already. If you like to print something for model or to color ,hope you will enjoy it. If you want to know more about the model, you can visit:
http://www.hkepc.com/forum/viewthread.php?tid=2199831&extra=page%3D1

Thing is still under construction! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AhxLo4NVtT8 This is a modification for a metal drive line. Therefore the central differential was modificated and also centered. The Steering got also and update and is now lying on the front plate. You need two Servo_Fuss_v2 to mount the servo to the bottom front plate. Also for this you have to change the steering_part_1 with *_part_2 and other way around. A metal driveline is definitely more stable and you can get even faster with your RC Car. Things to do:
  • new printable Servo arm
  • toe-in for rear wheels (stability reasons)
  • a moved drilling for top front plate and steering stabilizer connection
  • "Nachlauf" for front wheels and steering
    • For this metal driveline you need also this
    Central Differential
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:815023 and two of this differential housings
    Front/Rear Differential
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:631901 You can get the following parts at Hobbyking, eBay and Conrad.
    Metal Parts List:
    1x Central Diff from Hobbyking
    http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__16143__Central_Diff_Complete_1Pc_Bag_33154.html 1x Motor Pinion from Hobbyking
    http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__16142__Motor_Pinion_14T_and_Grub_Screw_1Pc_Bag_A2016T.html 2x HSP 02024 Diff Complete
    2x HSP 02030 Drive Gear
    1x HSP 02016 Universal Loint ( 1 pair )
    1x HSP 06022 87mm drive shafts ( 1 pair )
    4x Axial Narrow 12mm Aluminum Hub Hex AX30427 2x CVD Drive Shafts 118mm (2 pair)
    Outer Driveshafts - CVD 1:10 118MM – 4pcs (www.conrad.com #231121-I5) For more information and a construction manual you could also visit my blog:
    http://blog.hk-fs.de/2015/01/29/openrc-truggy/

A project requires us to fix nema17 steppers to the side of 45x45mm extrusions.

Two countersunk M5 screws will attach the support to the frame.   
Four M3 screws will hold the nema17 in place.  
Use the latest version of STL file, it is the one with a perfect fit for the M5 screws (at least for the ones I am using).
These are the 2 support legs (one for the FTDI board and one for the carrier itself).

This is a fan duct to better guide the flow of cool air towards the nozzle during extrusion.
It is specifically designed for the Arduino Materia 101 printer (or Sharebot Kiwi from which it derives).

I suggest printing it in 0.2mm layers. I printed mine in white PLA, 220°C for the first layer, 210°C for the following layers. The assembly requires:
  • 4x 6mm 3M bolts (2 to attach the assembly to the metal carriage, 2 to join the plastic parts together)
  • 4x 10mm 3M bolts (to fix the fan on the duct)

There was only one bottle holder but it only held 3 bottles and was made for a wall mount. This E-Juice stand will hold 16 bottles...1.350" holes should work for 15ml and 30ml. At least the ones I have....Conspiracy Liquids, Kure Blend, Charlie Noble, Space Jam, Twelve...etc.

This is just a flat stand.

comments.text:
UH...Chill...it was programmed in inches and you don't have your autodetect/conversion turned on. Just scale it to 2540% (converts inches to mm) and it will print to correct size.
Almost all front ends have an autodetect setting for programmed files....it will pop up and say "Model is too small. Scale to MMs?" when you have it turned on.....
